keywords: process for managing unpaid leave and corresponding salary adjustments
navigation_hints: Process for managing unpaid leave and corresponding salary adjustments

cognitive_walkthrough.goal: Find and validate Daily Wage Calculator feature

exploration_path.hint: Process for managing unpaid leave and corresponding salary adjustments

exploration_path.reason: Appears to be a workflow step, not a navigation element

evidence.breadcrumb: Unpaid Leave Request > Approval > Payroll Deduction Calculation
evidence.reason: Breadcrumb matches business workflow pattern (not a menu path)
evidence.note: This describes a business process workflow, not a clickable navigation path. Conceptual flows are documented for understanding the feature, not for UI navigation.

evidence.caveat: Navigation paths are from Zendesk docs (guidance only). Actual UI may differ.
Navigation paths are from Zendesk docs (guidance only). Actual UI may differ.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary by actual working days, excluding public holidays

checks.name: semantic_daily_pay_calculation
checks.claim_text: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary by actual working days, excluding public holidays
checks.validation_hint: Verify calculation matches: Total Salary / (Working Days - Public Holidays)

evidence.note: Business rule claim - validated with relaxed threshold

claim_ui_checks.claim: System supports both calendar days (30) and working days (22) leave policies

checks.name: semantic_leave_policy_types
checks.claim_text: System supports both calendar days (30) and working days (22) leave policies
checks.validation_hint: Confirm both policy types can be selected and correctly applied

claim_ui_checks.claim: User can access Daily Wage Calculator via Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_nav_001
checks.claim_text: User can access Daily Wage Calculator via Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
checks.validation_hint: Verify navigation path exists and leads to correct page

claim_ui_checks.claim: Calculator supports three calculation bases: calendar days, working days, custom days

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calc_002
checks.claim_text: Calculator supports three calculation bases: calendar days, working days, custom days
checks.validation_hint: Confirm all three calculation base options are available in UI

evidence.note: Business rule claim - validated with relaxed threshold

claim_ui_checks.claim: Super admin can navigate to Daily Wage Calculation through Settings > Payroll

checks.name: semantic_DWC_NAV_001
checks.claim_text: Super admin can navigate to Daily Wage Calculation through Settings > Payroll

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary calculation supports custom days, calendar days, and working days as basis

checks.name: semantic_DWC_CALC_001
checks.claim_text: Salary calculation supports custom days, calendar days, and working days as basis
checks.validation_hint: Verify all three calculation methods are available

evidence.note: Business rule claim - validated with relaxed threshold

claim_ui_checks.claim: Saving proration changes affects all active (unpaid) payroll amounts

checks.name: semantic_DWC_SAVE_001
checks.claim_text: Saving proration changes affects all active (unpaid) payroll amounts
checks.validation_hint: Confirm system updates all relevant transactions

claim_ui_checks.claim: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves.

checks.name: semantic_payroll_automation_gap
checks.claim_text: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system shows a discrepancy in daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll settings. The payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave deductions. The greyed-out display in leave policy indicates this override is intentional.

checks.name: semantic_formula_override_configuration
checks.claim_text: The system shows a discrepancy in daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll settings. The payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave deductions. The greyed-out display in leave policy indicates this override is intentional.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_calculation
checks.claim_text: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator is not correctly accounting for leap years in its calculation logic. When calculating gratuity for an employee with service spanning 2024 (a leap year), the system counts 365 days instead of 366 days for that year, resulting in an incorrect total service period (607 days instead of 608 days) and an incorrect gratuity amount (AED 10,476.98 instead of AED 10,494.24).

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_calculation_error
checks.claim_text: The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator is not correctly accounting for leap years in its calculation logic. When calculating gratuity for an employee with service spanning 2024 (a leap year), the system counts 365 days instead of 366 days for that year, resulting in an incorrect total service period (607 days instead of 608 days) and an incorrect gratuity amount (AED 10,476.98 instead of AED 10,494.24).

claim_ui_checks.claim: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

checks.name: semantic_eos_calculation_decimal_precision
checks.claim_text: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses specific methodologies for counting days, accounting for leap years, and applying different daily rates based on service duration.

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_complexity
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses specific methodologies for counting days, accounting for leap years, and applying different daily rates based on service duration.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing slight variations in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The specific case showed a difference between 912 and 913 total days, impacting the final calculation.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_calculation
checks.claim_text: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing slight variations in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The specific case showed a difference between 912 and 913 total days, impacting the final calculation.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (623 days instead of 622 days). Daily wage calculation uses a fixed divisor of 30 days, which differs from client's preferred method of (Basic × 12 / 365).

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_discrepancy
checks.claim_text: Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (623 days instead of 622 days). Daily wage calculation uses a fixed divisor of 30 days, which differs from client's preferred method of (Basic × 12 / 365).

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_variation
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. This is a system design limitation where leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage formulas.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_configuration
checks.claim_text: The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. This is a system design limitation where leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage formulas.

claim_ui_checks.claim: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_misunderstanding
checks.claim_text: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. When payroll is processed earlier than the departure date, the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

checks.name: semantic_salary_proration_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. When payroll is processed earlier than the departure date, the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_sync
checks.claim_text: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes out of sync between Payroll and Time Off modules. This results in incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_sync_issue
checks.claim_text: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes out of sync between Payroll and Time Off modules. This results in incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The payroll system uses a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations, potentially causing confusion about calculation methods.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_complexity
checks.claim_text: The payroll system uses a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations, potentially causing confusion about calculation methods.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

checks.name: semantic_remarks_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. Deductions are calculated using a global setting instead of policy-level basic salary / working days configuration.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_calculation_override
checks.claim_text: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. Deductions are calculated using a global setting instead of policy-level basic salary / working days configuration.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is inconsistent with the leave period.

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is inconsistent with the leave period.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary is calculated based on a standard 26 working days per month (365 annual days - 52 weekly offs = 313 working days / 12 months = 26.08 days)

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation
checks.claim_text: Salary is calculated based on a standard 26 working days per month (365 annual days - 52 weekly offs = 313 working days / 12 months = 26.08 days)

claim_ui_checks.claim: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration takes precedence over leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations

checks.name: semantic_formula_precedence_rules
checks.claim_text: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration takes precedence over leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

checks.name: semantic_salary_configuration_update_timing
checks.claim_text: Leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system defaults to 365-day years, failing to recognize leap years with 366 days in service period calculations.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_count
checks.claim_text: The system defaults to 365-day years, failing to recognize leap years with 366 days in service period calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Pro-rated amount calculations consistently show amounts less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimal points across all employee calculations.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_precision
checks.claim_text: Pro-rated amount calculations consistently show amounts less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimal points across all employee calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave days are accrued at end of month under monthly accrual policy, preventing mid-month leave balance inclusion in EOS

checks.name: semantic_leave_accrual_policy_constraint
checks.claim_text: Leave days are accrued at end of month under monthly accrual policy, preventing mid-month leave balance inclusion in EOS

claim_ui_checks.claim: Unclear rules for counting service days, specifically around departure date inclusion and leap year day handling

checks.name: semantic_service_duration_calculation
checks.claim_text: Unclear rules for counting service days, specifically around departure date inclusion and leap year day handling

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates partial years differently for service periods above 5 years, using specific day counting and divisor (365 or 366) based on leap year inclusion.

checks.name: semantic_partial_year_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: The system calculates partial years differently for service periods above 5 years, using specific day counting and divisor (365 or 366) based on leap year inclusion.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage is calculated using a fixed divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_fixed_divisor
checks.claim_text: Daily wage is calculated using a fixed divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave encashment can be calculated using either 'working days' (variable monthly rate) or 'custom days' (consistent rate)

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_configuration_method
checks.claim_text: Leave encashment can be calculated using either 'working days' (variable monthly rate) or 'custom days' (consistent rate)

claim_ui_checks.claim: The Bayzat platform calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors.

checks.name: semantic_independent_daily_wage_calculations
checks.claim_text: The Bayzat platform calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration is calculated based on the specific work week configuration, which may include all 7 days as working days

checks.name: semantic_work_week_proration_logic
checks.claim_text: Salary proration is calculated based on the specific work week configuration, which may include all 7 days as working days

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration only works correctly for departure dates in the past, not for future departure dates

checks.name: semantic_proration_date_sensitivity
checks.claim_text: Salary proration only works correctly for departure dates in the past, not for future departure dates

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system cannot automatically reconcile leave transactions with payroll deductions when modifications or deletions occur.

checks.name: semantic_leave_payroll_sync_limitation
checks.claim_text: The system cannot automatically reconcile leave transactions with payroll deductions when modifications or deletions occur.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system cannot recalculate daily wage deductions retroactively when public holidays are added after leave request processing.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_constraint
checks.claim_text: The system cannot recalculate daily wage deductions retroactively when public holidays are added after leave request processing.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage calculations must use the actual number of calendar days in a specific month, with special handling for February in leap years.

checks.name: semantic_calendar_days_calculation
checks.claim_text: Daily wage calculations must use the actual number of calendar days in a specific month, with special handling for February in leap years.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations

checks.name: semantic_global_configuration_precedence
checks.claim_text: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily rate is calculated as Basic + Allowances / Working Days, excluding public holidays

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: Daily rate is calculated as Basic + Allowances / Working Days, excluding public holidays

conceptual_flows.reason: Breadcrumb matches business workflow pattern (not a menu path)
